claim: Amoebas could have played a part in the Black Death.

supporting.text: Amoebas can harbor pathogenic bacteria, including Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of the Black Death, potentially acting as reservoirs or vectors.

attacks.text: Amoebas can harbor pathogenic bacteria, including Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of the Black Death, potentially acting as reservoirs or vectors.
There is no direct historical or archaeological evidence linking amoebas to the transmission of Yersinia pestis during the Black Death.
Amoebas are primarily aquatic organisms, whereas the Black Death spread rapidly through human populations via fleas on rodents, making amoeba involvement unlikely.
Laboratory studies show that Yersinia pestis can survive inside amoebas, but this does not prove amoebas played a role in the Black Death's epidemiology.
The environmental conditions required for amoebas to act as vectors (e.g., waterborne transmission) do not align with the known transmission routes of the Black Death.

supporting.text: Historical records and modern studies do not provide conclusive evidence linking amoebas to the transmission or spread of the Black Death.

attacks.text: Historical records and modern studies do not provide conclusive evidence linking amoebas to the transmission or spread of the Black Death.

The primary vectors for the Black Death were fleas and rats, as supported by overwhelming historical and genetic evidence.
While fleas and rats were dominant, other transmission routes, including amoebas, cannot be entirely ruled out due to incomplete historical data.
